attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical stock verification was conducted on April 17 2025, to confirm the reliability of inventory records by comparing actual stock levels with the data captured in the SAP system. The exercise also aimed to evaluate the strength of internal controls governing inventory management implemented  at the branch

·       Key findings from verification are as detailed below:

ü  Bread stock showed a shortage of 21 loaves.

ü  Polybags (packing materials) had a shortage of 1,366 pieces.

ü  White flour had an excess of 7.10 kgs.

ü  Utto (vegetable oil) recorded a deficit of 1.98 liters.

ü  Yeast and white ingredients reflected minor variances of 0.15 units, which are considered immaterial.

·       Below is the detailed summary of the audit findings:

Findings

·       The audit also revealed a recurring issue related to the unusual volume of bread deductions at the branch.

·       A total of 548.5 loaves valued at approximately Kshs 29,070 had been deducted as of the stock take date.

·       These deductions were consistently attributed to over-baking incidents as reported by oven men during the production process.

Implication:

The stock variances and recurring bread deductions point to inefficiencies in inventory management and production processes at the branch.

 Crates Verification

Findings           

·        A crate balance review was conducted at the branch on March 23, 2025 to assess whether the controls over crate movement were sufficient to mitigate the risk of crate loss.

·       The review found that the branch had an excess of 6 crates.

Implication:

The discovery of excess crates suggests that there may be inconsistencies or inefficiencies in the tracking and movement of crates between branches, which could result in unaccounted crates and instances of crates losses across the branches.
attributes.recommendation:
•  Branch management should reassign oven men involved in the over-baking issue to different roles and ensure training for new oven men.

  • The branch management should also monitor and ensure proper recording of damaged polybags are done at the packing section ideally at the end of every shift.

  • Branch management should develop a process to ensure crates that belong to other branches are correctly tracked and returned during subsequent stock takes.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To eliminate recurring stock variances by strengthening inventory control measures, improving accountability, and enhancing transparency in material usage and reporting.

Remediation Actions:

value:
·       Excessive consumption of FOC may be a primary contributor to the bread stock variances observed.

·       Inadequate controls over polybag usage and insufficient recording of damaged polybags at the branch may have also led to the discrepancies noted.

·       Going forward, we will closely monitor these areas to ensure proper documentation is maintained, with the aim of reducing and preventing such variances.

The controls in place shall be maintained. For extra crates this may belong to other branch and when stock shall be done they will then be returned.

·       The bread variance was minimal, primarily caused by excessive consumption of FOC or inaccurate record-keeping.

·       The bread deductions were largely due to over-baking by certain oven men. Given the consistency of this issue, we plan to reassign them to other sections and will train new oven men with potential candidates.

·       Inadequate control over polybag usage led to the observed negative variances.

There was a lack of follow-up in the damaged polybag recording process within the packing section, which contributed to improper issue management.

·       The frequency of crate movements between branches contributed to the accumulation of extra crates.

·       We will conduct a stock take across all branches to reconcile crate inventories.

Additionally, controls will be strengthened to prevent such discrepancies in the future.

·       In the prior audit report dated 13th March 2025, it was noted that:

ü  Polybags had a variance of +546 Pieces,

ü  Finished product had a variance of -211.5 Loaves for bread produced by the branch.

ü  Yeast had a variance of +0.41 Pcs.

ü  White flour had a variance of +20.44 Kgs.

White Ingredient had a variance of +0.41 Pcs

attributes.title: Bread weight analysis
attributes.description:
·       Packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market were randomly weighed to determine if they were of correct weight of 200g,400g,600g and 800g as per the KEBS standard weights.

·       Underweights were noted across the sampled varieties as seen below:

Ø  400g BT had 67%,

Ø  400g CT had 84%,

Ø  600g BT had 31%,

Ø  600g CT had 31%,

Ø  400g BW had 43%

Ø  600g BW had 8%

·       Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings:

Implication:

·       The presence of underweight bread in the market potentially subject the company to fines, penalties, or legal action from regulatory bodies.

·       Delivering underweight products can result in customer dissatisfaction, damaging the brand’s reputation and potentially leading to loss of market share.

Overweight bread could increase costs per unit, affecting profitability without necessarily increasing revenue.
attributes.recommendation: ·       In-line weight checks during production process should be strengthened to identify and address underweight or overweight products in real time.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure all bread products meet the required weight standards consistently thus maintaining product quality, customer satisfaction and compliance with KEBS regulations.

value:
·       On that day, an ill slicer caused delays which contributed to the overcooling of the bread. In such instances, we perform salvaging procedures, which can take additional time from the slicers.

·       Moving forward, we will closely monitor the process to ensure compliance with bread weight standards.

·       The jam issue occurred due to an employee operating the slicer falling ill the night before the bread weighing process. As a result, the bread needed to be salvaged, which took some time.

·       Due to the lack of sufficient time to arrange for a replacement, the bread experienced overcooling.

·       Moving forward, we will address the issue to ensure adherence to weight standards and prevent such occurrences.

·       In the previous audit report, dated 13th March 2025 bread underweights were noted as follows:

ü  400g - 19%,

ü  600g - 17%,

ü  800g - 29%,

ü  200g-21%.

·       Bread overweight for the period were as follows:

ü  400g-5%,

ü  600g-32%,

ü  800g-45%,

ü  200g-8%

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of production and market damages at the branch was conducted over a 33-day period from March 19 2025 to April 20 2025, to evaluate whether the damage rates were within the acceptable thresholds of 0.2% for production and 0.5% for market damages.

·        The review revealed that production damages accounted for 0.29% of total output, exceeding the allowable limit, and resulting in a cost impact of Ksh 28,557.42.

·       On the other hand, market damages stood at 0.42% of total sales, which was within the acceptable range.

·       NB: The analysis is exclusive of 180 Oven damages.

Implication:

·       Exceeding the set KPI of 0.2% production damages indicates inefficiencies in the baking process resulting in a direct cost.

The variation in customer satisfaction related to inter-branch bread transfers points to a lack of uniform quality standards across branches, indicating inconsistencies in product output that may not meet customer expectations.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management is encouraged to evaluate the effectiveness of current staff training especially the oven men, baking procedures and operational controls to determine if any additional measures or improvements can reduce damages.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To reduce bread damages in both production and market stages through improved handling, preventive maintenance, staff performance monitoring nd enhanced quality control processes.

value: Inconsistencies in oven performance contributed to production damages as the equipment does not ensure uniform baking where some loaves bake correctly, others may become over-baked, even when operating under the same time and control settings.

·       Market damages resulting from returns were primarily due to bread transfers from other branches, where customers favored specific product qualities typically associated with the receiving branch—qualities that the supplying branch’s bread did not consistently meet.

Production damages were significantly impacted by oven-related issues, with a high occurrence of over-baked
In the prior audit report dated 13th March 2025, it was noted that production damages were at 0.27% while market damages were at 0.38%.

attributes.title: Mixing chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the mixing chart and its summaries over the 33-day period from March 19to April 20 2025 was conducted to assess whether raw material consumption aligned with the established BOM and whether the targeted yield and quality standards were met during production.

·       The following were noted:

ü  The average yield was 192.93 loaves per bag

ü  Average production was 94.03 bags equivalent to 95.95% of the set target of 98 bags.

ü  Utto units’ consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1

ü   234 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:

Implication:

Un-attainment of production target indicate room for improvement in ideal production environment.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To enhance mixing process efficiency, reduce remixes and achieve full production targets by addressing equipment reliability, process accuracy and operational performance.

attributes.title: Minishop Spot Check
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the mini shop on April 23rd, 2025, to assess whether operations were being carried out in line with the established standards.

·       The audit focused on reconciling stock movements with recorded sales and confirming whether cash sales aligned with the expected sales figures.

·       Activities at minishop as at 23 April 2025 conformed with the set standards as both figures reconciled as detailed below:

Implication.

·       The spot check results indicate that operations at the Minishop are being conducted in line with the established procedures.

The effectiveness of current controls minimizes the risk of stock mismanagement and fraud.
attributes.recommendation: ·       Branch management should continue enforcing the existing control mechanisms, as they have proven effective in ensuring accurate stock and cash reconciliations.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To preserve the integrity and accuracy of minishop operations and ensure sustainability of effective control measures.

Action Plan

value: The control measures at Minishop are largely effective. We will continue to maintain them
The control measures at Minishop are largely effective. We will continue to maintain them

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balances as of April 22, 2025, was conducted to identify any long-outstanding receivables that may pose a risk of becoming bad debts.

·        Debtor balances were effectively managed, with no outstanding closing balances recorded, except for a few institutions with follow up from sales representative ongoing. These institutions are detailed :

Implication:

Continued focus on debtor policy at the branch supports healthy cash flow and minimizes financial risk from uncollected receivables.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The existing debtor management processes appear effective and should be maintained to ensure continued performance.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure timely collection of all receivables, prevent aging of debts and minimize exposure to bad debts, especially from institutional clients.

Action Plan

value: Controls in place are operating effectively. We shall maintain.
Controls in place are operating effectively. We shall maintain.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An assessment was conducted over a 33-day period from March 19 to April 20 2025 to evaluate the branch's production efficiency and determine whether production workers were meeting the target rate of 4.3 bags per worker.

·       It was observed that the production efficiency stood at 3.92 bags per production worker, falling short of the standard rate. This shortfall resulted in a cost impact of Kshs 74,975.40, and contributed to additional 69 workers being hired.

·       Below is the analysis of the production efficiency for the period under consideration.

Implication

Risk of recurring inefficiencies i.e. if systemic issues (machine reliability and staff management) are not addressed it may potentially impact profitability and resource planning in future periods.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should strengthen supervisory oversight by assigning accountable team leads for each production shift to reduce negligence and enforce work standards.

Branch management should also ensure that production equipment and ovens undergo routine inspections and maintenance to minimize the risk of breakdowns and avoid costly disruptions.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To restore and sustain production efficiency at or above 4.3 bags per worker, reduce excess labor costs and improve operational discipline.

value:
·       Machine breakdown has contributed to the noted lack of efficiency attainment.

We shall ensure efficiencies are attained at the branch in ideal situations

·       Inconsistences as a result of mixer machine breakdown and oven (two which has higher probability of getting breakdown) contributed to un-attainment of efficiency.

·       There was poor supervision of employees and negligence which shall be improved.

·       We shall confirm machine efficiency then ensure workers are pushed to attain targets and or ensure reshuffle.

Repair by KAF would not be reliable as after maintenance the issue would occur again.
The previous audit report dated 13th March 2025, it was noted that production efficiency was at 4.01 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An assessment of packer utilization in the slicing section was conducted over a 33-day period, from March 19 to April 20 2025, to determine whether performance met the company’s standard KPI of 97 crates per packer.

·       The evaluation indicated that the packing efficiency was 93.19 crates per packer, below the expected standard.

·       Consequently, 17 extra workers were brought on board, incurring an additional cost of Kshs 15,504.

Implication:

·       There is increased labor costs due to overstaffing, resulting from underperformance in packing efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should align hiring practices with actual output/production, ensuring that workforce levels reflect real-time production in order to control labor costs.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To achieve the target of 97 crates per packer, reduce excess staffing costs and enhance accountability and productivity in the packing section.

value:
·       The failure to meet efficiency targets has been partly attributed to negligence on the part of some packers.

We plan to formally communicate with HR regarding their behavior, including frequent sick leave patterns and some which are suspicious.

·       Hiring decisions will be based on actual production performance moving forward

Slicers are not consistently performing their tasks effectively. We shall ensure they perform as per expectations.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       A review of the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption was carried out over a 20-day period from April 1 to April 20 2025 to assess whether fuel usage was in line with the established standard and to determine if it was being utilized efficiently.

Findings:

·       Obama (KTWC 326Y) – Overconsumption attributed to a faulty speedometer (inoperative for 12 days).

·       Chokaa (KDB 236L), Loading (KDA 083Z) and Kayole 1 (KCN 076N) – Registered fuel consumption above standard levels, indicating possible inefficiencies or unmonitored fuel usage.

·       A detailed analysis is illustrated below below

Implication:

·       Mechanical issues such as faulty speedometers compromise the reliability of consumption data, potentially allowing fuel misuse to go unnoticed.

·       Fuel may not be allocated strictly based on kilometers covered, leading to potential misappropriation or inefficiencies.
attributes.recommendation: Immediate steps should be taken to recover costs related to routes/vehicles with unjustified overconsumption.

value: Noted. We will take appropriate recovery actions on routes with fuel overconsumption

·       Some vehicles in the fleet may be experiencing mechanical issues, such as faulty speedometers. These issues will be addressed and resolved.

Managers are also advised to allocate fuel based on the kilometers covered. Any excess fuel consumption should be recovered accordingly.

In the prior audit report dated 13th March 2025, it was noted that all route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard except for various routes Chokaa Route, Dandora route, Loader and Kayole 1 Route which had fuel overconsumption
